author: Brian Johnston
title: The lowdown on which of Rockies resort Aspen’s four mountains is the best for you
text:
THERE’S a lot to like about Aspen. It has charm and a sense of history, Colorado friendliness, great restaurants and bars.
Its reputation for celebrity glamour is somewhat misleading because this ski resort, while certainly often chic, is laid-back too, full of ski bums and young adventurers.
Most of all, Aspen has some of the world’s best skiing. Its champagne powder snow is legendary, yet it has many blue-sky days.
Four different mountains offer more runs than you could probably conquer in a week. Its only disadvantage is that, unlike many European resorts, they aren’t linked by lifts, though each is easily accessible by shuttle bus.
1. BUTTERMILK
If you want to start at the beginning, hit low-key Buttermilk on day one and get the ski legs going on 40-odd trails. This is Aspen’s least challenging ski area and often dismissed by more accomplished skiers as the destination for beginners, families and, thanks to its terrain park and Olympic half-pipe, snowboarders.
In my opinion (and I’m an advanced skier), Buttermilk is a rather lovely introduction to Aspen. Beginners will find green slopes even on the mountaintop, and those with more confidence ought to be happy swishing down well-groomed blue runs.
What many visitors don’t realise is that Buttermilk does, in fact, have black runs too, accessed off the somewhat ignored Tiehack Express lift. With good skiers generally off elsewhere, it’s almost like having your own private mini-resort for a half-day, with nobody else around to ruin your powder. Those with a need for speed will enjoy thundering down Racer’s Edge. Sterner might be my favourite run for its banked curves and length.
 Skiing the fresh powder on Aspen Mountain. Picture: Aspen Ski Company Source: Supplied
2. ASPEN MOUNTAIN
Aspen Mountain (Ajax to locals) is the best-known and most skied of the four mountains because its base gondola is on the edge of town. It’s the most crowded, with huddles sometimes building up at chairlifts and skiers funnelled into town down Spar Gulch at day’s end. Mind you, crowded is only a relative term in Aspen.
Ajax is the mountain for people watching and sitting on sun terraces. Chase down its pop-up champagne and caviar bar, which makes an appearance on Fridays, Saturdays and Sundays beneath bright orange umbrellas.
And the skiing? Ajax has nearly 80 trails. None of them are green but, unless you’re an absolute beginner, you’ll manage its many well-groomed blue runs, which lead you all the way from top to bottom. Ski the old Roch Cup downhill race route, which follows Ruthie’s and Roch runs, for an epic cruiser.
You might first fortify yourself near the top of Ruthie’s with sausages and sauerkraut at Bonnie’s. For location alone (the venue itself is more cafeteria than restaurant), Bonnie’s is my favourite pit-stop on Ajax, with a huge terrace looking over the ski slopes and mountains beyond.
Accomplished skiers can do summit to base in under 10 minutes: pure, swooping exhilaration all the way. On the whole, confident (or reckless) intermediates and experts will be most satisfied with Aspen Mountain.
Interesting moguls provide double-black diamond challenges, especially on a series of parallel runs off International, collectively known as The Dumps, where locals head on powder days. Across the valley, Face of Bell and Ridge of Bell also favour those looking for bumps and powder.
My other tip for finding fresh powder is to drop into Kristi or Walsh’s runs (the latter is a snowboarding favourite), then track lower to Bingo Glades and Jackpot.
 Snowmass is generally an intermediate skier’s mountain. Picture: Aspen Ski Company Source: Supplied
3. SNOWMASS
By the standards of most ski resorts, Ajax alone would be satisfying but, in Aspen, it’s trumped by Snowmass, which has many more runs, the steepest ski run (Hanging Valley Wall) in Aspen, and more vertical metres than any other North American ski resort.
Lower slopes are interknitted blues, upper slopes plunging double-blacks. Runs are nice and wide, where they can be narrow on Ajax. Snowmass is generally an intermediate skier’s mountain, even if it does offer significant challenges too. You can enjoy long cruises around Elk Camp or push your expertise between-tree trails on Sam’s Knob or off High Alpine lift.
Snowmass is snowboarding territory as well. Trail maps specify which trails are snowboard friendly and which to avoid for their flatter terrain. The black-rated Cirque Headwall is the centre of the action, but there are also several terrain areas and a superpipe and pipe accessed from Coney Glade lift.
If you’re going to eat on the mountain, aim for Sam’s Smokehouse, where you get Texas and southern-style barbecued meats accompanied by beans, corn muffins and great views.
Snowmass also has considerable accommodation and a purpose-built base town which, though lacking the charm of historic Aspen, is mostly ski-in ski-out and family friendly. Skiers are up early, when the late-night revellers of Aspen are still sleeping in.
 An uphill hike takes skiers to the pitches of the Highlands Bowl. Picture: Aspen Ski Company Source: Supplied
4. ASPEN HIGHLANDS
Local hard-core skiers talk of this final mountain with a gleam in their eye. That’s mostly because of Highland Bowl, which offers a series of runs with 45-degree pitches reached on an initial 30-minute uphill hike. It’s one of skiing’s great challenges that keeps you within bounds but feels like a back-country adventure.
If you’re looking for vertical drop, ski the runs in the Temerity and Steeplechase areas, then head over to Olympic Bowl in the afternoon and work down the lines.
If you aren’t an advanced skier, don’t be put off Highlands, however. A look at the trail map shows 119 runs, with blues and even greens embedded among all those blacks with off-putting names like The Wall and Moment of Truth. Blue runs will take you from top to bottom. What’s more, the Maroon Bells peaks are magnificent, providing Aspen’s best scenery.
Personally, my favourite run on the whole mountain is the easy-rated Red Onion, where great natural terrain and rollers provide a happiness-inducing downhill glide. The blue-rated Thunderbowl is another merry trail and very wide compared with Highland’s mostly narrow tree runs.
Folk on Highlands ski hard and party hard too. Book a late-lunch table at Cloud Nine Alpine Bistro high on the mountain for a quintessential Highlands experience. The legendary dining spot features fondue, raclette and elk stroganoff.
Afterwards, taking the unsuspecting by surprise, a DJ cranks up the music, loud enough to shake the windowpanes. Veuve Clicquot flows and patrons dance on bench tops. Then everyone skis their final run, bellies full and cheeks creased as a Cheshire cat’s.
The writer travelled as a guest of Travelplan Ski and Colorado Ski Country USA.
 Skiing in Aspen Highlands. Picture: Aspen Ski Company Source: Supplied

GETTING THERE
Travelplan Ski can organise flights from Australia to Aspen. See travelplan.com.au or ph 1300 754 754.
STAYING THERE
Limelight Lodge has large rooms and complimentary services including airport and ski transport and ski valets. Some packages include lift tickets. See limelighthotel.com
Hotel Jerome is a historic 1880s hotel in which Victorian and contemporary styles merge. It has a good restaurant and great bars. See hoteljerome.aubergeresorts.com
EATING THERE
Cloud Nine Alpine Bistro, top of Cloud Nine lift, Aspen Highlands. See aspensnowmass.com
Jimmy’s Bodega, 305 South Mill Street; visit jimmysaspen.com
Matsushita Aspen, 303 East Main Street; visit matsuhisaaspen.com
Sam’s Smokehouse, top of Village Express lift in Snowmass; visit aspensnowmass.com
